As I am still trying to understand that, let me comment a few things. 

1. =
The CPPN cannot have problem-specific inputs, because it is not 
the networ=
k that solves the problem. It is the genotype of the 
network solving the p=
roblem. 

2. Auxiliary additional parameters associated with problem specif=
ic 
inputs are just additional problem specific inputs. There is a big 
dif=
ference. The geometry is given to the CPPN only. And it is the 
only thing =
that a CPPN needs to work. 

3. "the quantity and meaning of auxiliary addi=
tional parameters 
  associated w/ PSIs (1-b) can vary over the substrate n=
etwork (i.e. 
  dimensionality of substrate inputs, hidden and output nodes=
) "

It's like telling me that the 3D space around me can twist and bend 
b=
ecause of the complexity of my organism. You have to understand that 
the C=
PPN network has nothing to do with the substrate. I can take a 
connective =
CPPN and turn it into a spatial CPPN that draws pictures 
without losing it=
s capability to create complex connective patters, 
for example. 

 * * * 
=

At this point, I see your generalization as defining a higher-
dimentional=
 space (the design space), where the phenotype/genotype 
spaces are subspac=
es in it. I think this is a wrong way for 
generalizing HyperNEAT, because =
it implies that the genotype space is 
dependant of the phenotype space or =
there is a bi-directional 
connection between them. This is not the case in=
 fact. Genotypes 
cannot change. The genotype is given a fitness score, but=
 it is the 
phenotype that is evaluated. The genotype maps to the phenotype=
 in 
some way. The problem-specific inputs/outputs can exist in the 
phenot=
ype space only. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@...=
> wrote:
>
> The following is a proposed generalization of the HyperNEAT co=
ncept 
> from its present implementation. The objectives are two-fold. 
Fir=
st, 
> to expand the scope of problems in which the HyperNEAT approach may =

> be applied. Second, to enable evolved partition of the design 
space, 
>=
 so as to enable application of the HyperNEAT approach to problems 
> which=
 contain highly discontinuous and divergent natures in 
different 
> portio=
ns of the design space. It is intended to provide a starting 
> point for f=
urther thought and interchange of ideas, with the focus 
on 
> achieving th=
e stated objectives by whatever means or changes which 
> may emerge.
> 
> =
1 - Preliminary Definitions: Given an arbitrary point "P" in design 
> spac=
e, comprised of the following:
> (a) problem specific inputs (PSIs);
> (b) =
auxiliary additional parameters associated w/ PSIs (i.e. 
includes 
> geome=
try);
> (c) problem specific outputs (PSOs);
> (d) auxiliary additional par=
ameters associated w/ PSOs (i.e. 
includes 
> geometry);
> (e) Substrate In=
puts: comprised of PSIs, "a" above;
> (f) Substrate Outputs: comprised of P=
SOs, "c" above;
> (g) CPPN Inputs: comprised of auxiliary additional parame=
ters 
> associated w/ PSIs & PSOs, "b" & "d" above;
> (h) CPPN Output: weig=
ht between current pair of substrate nodes;
> (i) An "experience_point" is =
defined as a struct containing 
items "a" 
> through "d" above;
> (j) The "=
Experience" is defined as a vector of experience_points;
> 
> 2 - Current H=
yperNEAT Implementation:
> (a) CPPN Inputs comprised of (1-b) and (1-d) are=
 each constant in 
> number and meaning as you loop over the links in the s=
ubstrate 
> network (i.e. 3D CPPN "From" Input: quan. =3D 3, meaning =3D X,=
 Y & Z 
> coordinates)
> 
> 3 - Proposed Generalization For CPPN Input:
> (=
a) the quantity and meaning of auxiliary additional parameters 
> associate=
d w/ PSIs (1-b) can vary over the substrate network (i.e. 
> dimensionality=
 of substrate inputs, hidden and output nodes);
> (b) the quantity and mean=
ing of auxiliary additional parameters 
> associated w/ PSOs (1-d) can vary=
 over the substrate network (i.e. 
> dimensionality of substrate inputs, hi=
dden and output nodes);
> (c) CPPN Input "From": the quantity and meanings =
are defined to be 
> the superset of possible auxiliary additional paramete=
rs associated 
> w/ PSIs and PSOs (i.e. 5D CPPN "From" Input: quan. =3D 5, =
meaning =3D 
X, 
> Y, Z, apples & oranges);
> (d) CPPN Input "To": the quan=
tity and meanings are defined to be 
the 
> superset of possible auxiliary =
additional parameters associated w/ 
> PSIs and PSOs (i.e. 5D CPPN "To" Inp=
ut: quan. =3D 5, meaning =3D X, Y, 
Z, 
> apples & oranges);
> (e) the mean=
ing of any given CPPN Input node, for both "From" 
> or "To", remains const=
ant (i.e. only apples are presented on the 
> apples input node);
> (f) the=
 quantity of zero is presented on any CPPN Input node whose 
> dimensionali=
ty, or meaning, is not present/applicable for the 
current 
> CPPN Input "F=
rom" or "To";
> 
> 4 - Proposed Generalization For Evolved Partition of Des=
ign Space:
> (a) Evaluation of speciation of CPPN population along design s=
pace 
> partition lines, as defined by allocation of experience_points 
> a=
ddressed by a specific species (i.e. species "0" by default 
> addresses al=
l experience_points, species "1" through "n" addresses 
> only those experi=
ence_points which yield a higher absolute fitness 
> than species "0";
> (b=
) species fitness computed based upon percentage of 
> experience_points yi=
elding a highest absolute fitness among all 
> species (i.e. if species "1"=
 gave best fitness for 25 percent of 
the 
> experience_points, then the sp=
ecies fitness would be the summation 
of 
> fitness for those specific expe=
rience_points);
> (c) objective to maximize overall fitness of "Experience"=
 as 
> summation of best individual from each species over those 
> experie=
nce_points for which they were evolved and maintained the 
best 
> fitness =
(i.e. all experience_points addressed only once);
